intro: Scorzonera caerulea, commonly known as blue scurvy grass, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the Arctic and alpine regions of Europe and Asia. It is characterized by its basal rosette of narrow, blue-green leaves and produces striking blue to violet flowers in the summer. The plant is adapted to cold climates and thrives in well-drained, rocky soils. Its flowers are typically borne on elongated stems and are visited by various pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Scorzonera caerulea is also known for its edible roots, which have been historically used in traditional medicine and cuisine.
